note.p: If you do not modify or configure a parameter in the VNF Extension file before instantiation, leave this parameter unchanged and assigned to its default value as defined in the current NCC release. To modify the default settings of any parameter, see the description of the parameter.

conbody.p: The following table describes the VNF Extension parameters. For information on the storage parameters, see .

entry.p: This parameter is configured and used only if the following applies:

li.p: The ComSvc VMs (that include the containers) use IPv6.
The external networks of ComSvc VMs and containers must be of the same IP version. If the external network of ComSvc is IPv6, then the containers’ external network must also be IPv6.

entry.p: This parameter defines the list of /80 IPv6 subnets. The subnets in this list are separated by the comma character (,).
For example,
The number of IPv6 subnets in this list must be equal or greater than the number of VMs to be deployed. A full /80 IPv6 subnet must be reserved for each VM.
Each /80 IPv6 subnet must be a slice of the external IPv6 subnet attached to the VMs.
Each VM uses its reserved /80 IPv6 subnet to assign IPv6 addresses to local containers.

row.entry: Must update if IPv6 external network is used for ComSvc VMs.

entry.p: This parameter defines the prefix section of the VM hostname and is applied to all the VMs of a particular site. It is applicable to both VMware and Openstack.

The VM hostname is automatically created based on the definitions captured in the HOT files that are part of the CSAR package. The VM hostname is a concatenation of several parts and is defined as <hostname_prefix>-<VM name segment>-<numeric index>, for example, sps-me1-auxiliary-2
where:

li.p: sps-me1 is <hostname_prefix>. Note, the dash character can be used in <hostname_prefix>.
auxiliary is <VM name segment> that is defined for every VM type. For the complete list of VM name segments, see .
2 is <numeric index> that consists of 1-3 digits.

entry.p: The length of <hostname_prefix> is bound by the maximum length of the VM hostname. According to RFC 1035, RFC-952 and RFC-1123, the VM hostname’s maximum length is 63 characters. The VM hostname is defined with up to 63 alphanumeric and dash (-) characters. Note, that the dot (.) and underscore (_) characters cannot be used in the VM hostname.
The 63 characters of the VM hostname are used as follows:

li.p: 2 characters are reserved for two dash delimiters.
3 characters are reserved for <numeric index>.
13 characters are reserved for <VM name segment>.

Up to 47 characters can be used for <hostname_prefix>. Although <hostname_prefix> might contain as little as 6 characters only, but for customer deployments and according to the VNF naming convention requirement, the minimum length of <hostname_prefix> should be 25 characters.

entry.p: To support the VNF naming convention requirement, this parameter must align with both <vnf_name> and the VNF name used in CBAM for this VNF.
Must update.
Ensure that the updated value matches the following:

li.p: <topology/spssite/spssiteid/name> parameter in the NCC section
-logrotate keys
-keys of mariadb/bootstr ap_nodes
<topology/spspartition/<partitionid>/name> parameter in the NCC section

entry.p: For more information, see .

row.entry:
The following is applicable only to VMware when the Resource Naming Convention is 4.
The VM hostname is a concatenation of several parts and is defined as
<hostname_prefix><name_separator><VM name segment for res_name4><name_separator><vnf_type_indicator><name_separator><numeric_index>for example,
Resource Naming Convention is 4
hostname_prefix is sps-me1
name_separator is "-"
vnf_type_indicator is sv1
res_name_suffix_start_value is 1
res_name_suffix_length is 3
in case of auxiliary, the VM hostname will be sps-me1-aux-sv1-001
See for details on VM name segment for res_name4.

entry.p: This parameter is used to identify the VNF's name. To support the VNF naming convention requirement, this parameter must be defined with up to 47 alphanumeric and dash (-) characters. The minimum length of <vnf_name> is 6 characters. However, for customer deployments and according to the VNF naming convention requirement, the minimum length of <vnf_name> should be 25 characters. Note that the dot (.) and underscore (_) characters cannot be used in <vnf_name>.
This parameter must align with both <hostname_prefix> and the VNF name used in CBAM for this VNF.
This parameter allows to enable or disable the automatic localization and startup of the NCC Application and Aerospike database.
The only values supported are “true” and “false”.
By default, this parameter is set to true and must be left untouched. This parameter is set to false only by Nokia personnel for debugging and testing purposes.
The values of true and false are case sensitive and must be in lowercase.

row.entry: Do not modify unless an NCC procedure explicitly requires it.

entry.p: This parameter defines the Network Time Protocol (NTP) server configuration. It follows the NTP protocol specification defined under the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) standards. One or several NTP severs can be listed and configured.
The format of the string for a single NTP server is as follows:
entry.codeblock: <NTP server IP or name>,<NTP version>,<NTP server's preference indicator>
entry.p: Each server contains the following elements separated by the comma char (,) :

li.p: <NTP server IP or name> is used to list the NTP server's IP address or the NTP server's name.

<NTP version> is used to list the NTP server's NTP version used and is based on the IETF NTP versions supported. It uses a numeric value in the interval [1,4]. The numeric value can be entered, or the entry can be left empty and the NTP server's value is automatically discovered and used.

<NTP server's preference indicator>defines if the NTP server is the preferred server when multiple NTP servers are used. One of the NTP servers listed must be set to preferred server. It uses a string that can be set to y (for "yes") or n (for "no").

entry.p: The format supports listing several NTP servers and delimiting the above single NTP server format by the vertical bar character (|), as follows:
entry.codeblock: "<NTP server#1 IP or name>,<NTP version>,<NTP server's preference indicator>|<NTP server#2 IP or name>,<NTP version>,<NTP server's preference indicator>|etc."
entry.p: Following is an example with three NTP servers being used:
This parameter is used on the auxiliary VM only for the ETCD datastore mounting.
Following are the supported mounting options:

li.p: "ram"

entry.p: where:

li.p: “cinder” is used for production deployment.
local is used for debugging and testing purposes inside Nokia. This option does not support any other LCM operations except for instantiate (for example, SU, backup and restore, and others).
ram is used for debugging and testing purposes inside Nokia. This option does not support any other LCM operations except for instantiate (for example, SU, backup and restore and others).

entry.p: This parameter defines the time zone that the VNFs will use.
It is essential that this parameter's value is correctly set for all the VNFs deployed in a particular time zone.
On every VM, this will set the timezone in Linux, by updating the /etc/localtime with the appropriate timezone file from /usr/share/zoneinfo based on the value entered for this parameter.
For example, if the value is set to "America/Toronto", then the following will be seen on the VMs:

row.entry: This parameter is specific to each site and is used for service discovery and configuration parameters. For more information, see Step 1 in the procedure .
This parameter defines the name of the OVF template which is used for VMware deployment. This parameter’s value must be the same as the name of the template uploaded to vCloud.

entry.p: This parameter defines the IPv6 network configuration of a particular site. However, the current VMware VCD version does not support IPv6 configuration.
This parameter is only used in JavaScript for VMWare with IPv6.
Value: "Reserved" or network parameter.

row.entry: Must update if IPv6 external network is used for ComSvc VMs.

entry.p: This parameter defines whether or not a VNF stays in the OOS state after this VNF has been instantiated.
The default value of this parameter should only be changed if an NCC procedure explicitly requires it.
The values are true or false.
The values of true and false are case sensitive and must be in lowercase.

row.entry: Update the default value only if an NCC procedure explicitly requires it.
This parameter must be set to true to use authconfig and the External LDAP authentication for Linux feature; otherwise, it should remain false (default).
Update the default value only if External LDAP authentication with Linux is explicitly required.

entry.p: This parameter defines the prefix added in front of vApp name to make vApp name more meaningful (vApp name is provided by CBAM). This parameter applies to VMware deployments only.
This parameter is an alphanumeric expression that must not contain the following:

li.p: VNFD value or this regex pattern CBAM-[0-9a-f]{32}. This means that this parameter cannot contain sequences that consist of CBAM- followed by any alphanumeric combination of 32 characters. For example, CBAM-b82e9d60d613450db69f5351aa68a33d is an invalid value for this parameter.
Any special characters such as backslash (/), forward slash (\) or percent (%).

entry.p: The maximum length of this parameter depends on the actual vCloud configuration and CBAM requirements. For example, in vCloud Director 8.20 (NFV 2.0.1), vApp name is restricted to 128 characters, and CBAM uses 74 character-long vApp names without prefix. Thus, this parameter can be maximum 54 characters long (128 vCloud Director limit - 74 CBAM limit). In addition, a delimiter such as dash (-) at the end of this parameter is recommended to increase readability, for example, SPS_IG_11_1_XX_111-.
For information on the supported NFV version, see the NCC Release Note. For the actual vCloud configuration, see the VMware site.
If this parameter is not specified, no prefix is set on newly created vApps in vCloud and the prefixes are removed from the existing vApp names.

row.entry:
This parameter defines the prefix section of the VM name present/seen on VDC and is applied to all the VMs of a particular site. This parameter is only valid for VMWare. Not available for openstack.
The length of <vm_name_prefix> is bound by the maximum length of the VM hostname. According to RFC 1035, RFC-952 and RFC-1123, the VM hostname’s maximum length is 63 characters. The VM name is defined with up to 63 alphanumeric and dash (-) characters. Note, that the dot (.) and underscore (_) characters cannot be used in the VM hostname.
If Resource Naming Convention is 1 (1 is default value of Resource Naming Convention), then vm_name_prefix be left as blank during upgrade. In this case, vnf_name will be used as vm_name_prefix.
The VM name is a concatenation of several parts and is defined as <vm_name_prefix>-<VM name segment>-<numeric index>, for example, sps-vm1-auxiliary-2 where: - sps-vm1 is <vm_name_prefix>. Note, the dash character can be
used in <vm_name_prefix>.
- auxiliary is <VM name segment> that is defined for every VM type. For the complete list of VM name segments, see Table 2-2, “Images” (p. 24).
- 2 is <numeric index> that consists of 1-3 digits.
Parameter is only in effect when Resource Naming Convention is 4, then vm_name_prefix is mandatory.

entry.p: The VM name is a concatenation of several parts and is defined as
<vm_name_prefix><name_separator><VM name segement for res4><name_separator><vnf_type_indicator><name_separator><numeric index>,
For example,
Resource Naming Convention is 4
vm_name_prefix is sps-vm1
for details on VM name segment for res_name4.
name_separator is "-"
vnf_type_indicator is sv1
res_name_suffix_start_value is 1
res_name_suffix_length is 3
in case of auxiliary, the VM name will be sps-vm1-aux-sv1-001
See
This parameter is only valid for VMWare. It is not available for openstack.
This parameter defines the prefix section of the computer name present/seen on VDC and is applied to all the VMs of a particular site.

The length of <computer_name_prefix> is bound by the maximum length of the VM hostname. According to RFC 1035, RFC-952 and RFC-1123, the VM hostname’s maximum length is 63 characters. The computer name is defined with up to 63 alphanumeric and dash (-) characters. Note, that the dot (.) and underscore (_) characters cannot be used in the VM hostname.
The computer name is a concatenation of several parts and is defined as
<computer_name_prefix><name_separator><VM name segement for res4><name_separator><vnf_type_indicator><name_separator><numeric index>,

row.entry: Update if required, applies to res_naming_convention=4

entry.p: for example,
Resource Naming Convention is 4
computer_name_prefix is sps-comp1
name_separator is "-"
vnf_type_indicator is sv1
for details on VM name segment for res_name4.
res_name_suffix_start_value is 1
res_name_suffix_length is 3
in case of auxiliary, the computer name will be sps-comp1-aux-sv1-001
See
This parameter is only valid for VMWare. It is not available for openstack.
This parameter is only in effect when Resource Naming Convention is 4.
Possible values are hypen "-" or can be left as blank "".
This parameter is used for defining hostname, VM name and computer name on VDC.
<prefix><name_separator><VM name segement for res4><name_separator><vnf_type_indicator><name_separator><numeric index>
Update if required, applies to res_naming_convention=4
Ensure that the updated value
matches the following:
- logrotate keys
- keys of mariadb/bootstrap_nodes
For example,
Resource Naming Convention is 4
computer_name_prefix is sps-comp1
name_separator is ""
vnf_type_indicator is sv1
for details on VM name segment for res_name4.
res_name_suffix_start_value is 1
res_name_suffix_length is 3
then computer name will be sps-comp1auxsv1001
See
This parameter is only valid for VMWare. It is not available for openstack.
This parameter is only in effect when Resource Naming Convention is 4.
The values are usually sv for server (others are for example, rt=router, lb=loadbalancer, fw=firewall)
The values are case sensitive. For example, sv1, sv2.
This parameter is used for defining hostname, VM name and computer name on VDC.
<prefix><name_separator><VM name segement for res4><name_separator><vnf_type_indicator><name_separator><numeric index>
Update if required, applies to res_naming_convention=4
Ensure that the updated value
matches the following:
- logrotate keys
- keys of mariadb/bootstrap_nodes
For example,
Resource Naming Convention is 4
computer_name_prefix is sps-comp1
name_separator is "-"
for details on VM name segment for res_name4.
vnf_type_indicator is SV1
res_name_suffix_start_value is 1
res_name_suffix_length is 3
then computer name will be sps-comp1-aux-SV1-001
See
